Federated Learning With Energy Harvesting Devices: An MDP Framework

Kai Zhang† and Xuanyu Cao† (IEEE Senior Member)
†Department of Electronic and Computer Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) requires edge devices to perform local training and exchange information with a parameter server, leading to substantial energy consumption. A critical challenge in practical FL systems is the rapid energy depletion of battery-limited edge devices, which curtails their operational lifespan and affects the learning performance. To address this issue, we apply energy harvesting technique in FL systems to extract ambient energy for continuously powering edge devices. We first establish the convergence bound for the wireless FL system with energy harvesting devices, illustrating that the convergence is impacted by partial device participation and packet drops, both of which depend on the energy supply. To accelerate the convergence, we formulate a joint device scheduling and power control problem and model it as a Markov decision process (MDP). By solving this MDP, we derive the optimal transmission policy and demonstrate that it possesses a monotone structure with respect to the battery and channel states. To overcome the curse of dimensionality caused by the exponential complexity of computing the optimal policy, we propose a low-complexity algorithm, which is asymptotically optimal as the number of devices increases. Furthermore, for unknown channels and harvested energy statistics, we develop a structure-enhanced deep reinforcement learning algorithm that leverages the monotone structure of the optimal policy to improve the training performance. Finally, extensive numerical experiments on real-world datasets are presented to validate the theoretical results and corroborate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, energy harvesting, Markov decision process, monotone structure, the curse of dimensionality, deep reinforcement learning.

I Introduction

Machine learning is a cornerstone technology driving artificial intelligence (AI) in diverse fields, such as autonomous driving [1] and the Internet of Things [2]. Traditional centralized machine learning requires the aggregation and processing of distributed data on a central server, which leads to increased data traffic and raises concerns about data privacy and security. To address these issues, federated learning (FL) has emerged as a novel distributed machine learning paradigm that enables collaborative model training without uploading raw data to a central server[3]. In FL, edge devices (e.g., mobile phones and sensors) conduct local training on their respective datasets and subsequently exchange information (e.g., model parameters or gradients) with a parameter server. Due to its distinctive architecture, FL can alleviate the computation and communication burdens and preserve the data privacy of involved edge devices [4, 5].

In practical scenarios, the performance of FL is severely affected by radio resources, such as transmission power and bandwidth. The limited radio resources among participating edge devices hinder data transmission and increase communication latency, degrading the learning performance. To tackle these issues, numerous papers have investigated communication resource management for wireless FL systems. In [6], the authors investigated a joint radio resource allocation and user selection problem for wireless FL, aiming to minimize the training loss under delay and energy consumption constraints. A similar resource allocation problem of achieving the optimal tradeoff between convergence speed and power consumption for wireless FL was studied in [7]. In [8], the authors developed a joint computation and transmission scheme for wireless FL under a more challenging setting with heterogeneous data. While the aforementioned studies explored static resource allocation according to the statistical properties of wireless channels, other research focused on the dynamic allocation of communication resources. The authors of [9] proposed a dynamic power control policy based on instant channel state information (CSI) to speed up the convergence of over-the-air FL. Similarly, a dynamic device scheduling and power control scheme for over-the-air FL was developed in [10]. Bandwidth allocation for wireless FL has also been studied extensively. In [11], the authors investigated a joint device selection and bandwidth allocation problem for wireless FL, devising an online algorithm to maximize the number of participating devices in each round. A similar problem incorporating latency constraints was studied in [12]. Additionally, the authors of [13] studied a joint power and bandwidth allocation problem to simultaneously minimize the power consumption, computation cost, and time cost of wireless FL systems.

Despite the extensive research, all the aforementioned studies have either considered finite energy supply for edge devices or completely neglected the energy limitations. However, merely utilizing the finite energy stored in the batteries of edge devices will lead to a reduced operational lifespan. Once the battery is depleted, edge devices cannot contribute to the training process of FL, which degrades the learning performance. Additionally, frequent battery replacements and recharges are impractical, especially for devices deployed in remote or inaccessible environments. To address this issue, energy harvesting (EH) FL has emerged as a promising solution. This technique collects ambient energy (e.g., solar, wind or thermoelectric energy) to continuously power edge devices, thereby extending their operational lifetime and improving the learning performance. Furthermore, EH FL uses clean and renewable energy sources, making it more environmentally friendly compared to conventional FL with battery-powered edge devices. Several recent studies have investigated EH FL. In [14], a client scheduling algorithm was introduced to accelerate the convergence of FL over EH-enabled wireless networks. A joint device selection and resource allocation problem was investigated in [15] to reduce training latency and improve the data utility of EH FL. The authors of [16] extended this problem to a more sophisticated system, where the server employs massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) to serve clients. Exploiting the over-the-air computation, the authors of [17] proposed a bandwidth-efficient scheme for joint client selection and energy management in EH FL. In [18], a joint client selection and bandwidth allocation scheme was designed for FL with EH devices, aiming to minimize the ages of local models and the latency of global iterations. To accelerate the convergence of EH FL, the authors of [19] formulated a joint transceiver design and device scheduling problem and developed a Lyapunov-based online optimization algorithm to solve it.

The prior works [14, 15, 16, 17, 18] on EH FL concentrate on designing transmission strategies for one typical time slot. However, the overall performance of FL is affected by the cumulative model aggregation errors over the entire training period, necessitating careful utilization of harvested energy from a long-term perspective. We note that [19] is an early attempt to optimize the long-term efficiency of EH FL. However, its online optimization algorithm fails to exploit the statistical knowledge of system dynamics, e.g., the distributions of the channel gains and the amount of harvested energy, resulting in suboptimal learning performance. Thus, in this paper, we are motivated to develop a Markov decision process (MDP) framework for designing the optimal transmission policy of EH FL. The proposed MDP framework utilizes the statistical knowledge of channels and harvested energy to address their inherent stochastic nature, thereby enabling efficient utilization of harvested energy and enhanced learning performance. The main contributions are summarized as follows.

1) We characterize the convergence bound of the wireless FL system with EH devices, demonstrating the impacts of partial device participation and packet drops, both of which further depend on the energy supply. Based on the convergence bound, we formulate a joint device scheduling and power control problem to minimize the optimality gap between the expected and optimal global loss.

2) We propose an MDP framework for the formulated optimality gap minimization problem and compute the optimal transmission policy. We prove that the optimal policy exhibits a monotone structure with respect to the battery and channel states. Moreover, to overcome the curse of dimensionality caused by the exponential complexity of computing the optimal policy, we propose a low-complexity algorithm that is asymptotically optimal as the number of devices increases.

3) For a more general scenario with unknown channels and harvested energy statistics, we develop a structure-enhanced deep reinforcement learning (SE-DRL) algorithm that leverages the monotone structure of the optimal policy to improve the training performance.

4) We validate the theoretical results and evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithms on real-world datasets. Numerical experiments demonstrate that the proposed algorithms outperform benchmark schemes in terms of test accuracy. The impact of battery capacity is also investigated.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we elaborate on the system model. In Section III, we conduct the convergence analysis and formulate the design problem accordingly. In Section IV, we develop an MDP framework and compute its optimal policy. In Section V, we propose an asymptotically optimal policy with low complexity. In Section VI, we develop an SE-DRL algorithm. Simulation results are presented in Section VII, and we conclude the paper in Section VIII.

II System Model

II-A Federated Learning Model

We consider a wireless FL system, where N𝑁N edge devices collaboratively train a common learning model 𝒘=[w1,…,wd]∈ℝd𝒘subscript𝑤1…subscript𝑤𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{w}=[w_{1},\ldots,w_{d}]\in\mathbb{R}^{d} under the coordination of a parameter server, as shown in Fig. 1. Each edge device n𝑛n has a local dataset 𝒟n={(𝒙n,i,yn,i)}i=1Dnsubscript𝒟𝑛superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n}=\{(\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i})\}_{i=1}^{D_{n}} with Dn=|𝒟n|subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝒟𝑛D_{n}=|\mathcal{D}_{n}| data samples, where 𝒙n,i∈ℝdsubscript𝒙𝑛𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is the i𝑖i-th input feature vector of device n𝑛n and yn,isubscript𝑦𝑛𝑖y_{n,i} is its corresponding label. Then, the global dataset is given by 𝒟=⋃n=1N𝒟n𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}=\bigcup_{n=1}^{N}\mathcal{D}_{n} with D=∑n=1NDn𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝐷𝑛D=\sum_{n=1}^{N}D_{n} data samples. Let f​(𝒘;𝒙n,i,yn,i)𝑓𝒘subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖f(\boldsymbol{w};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}) denote the sample-wise loss function, which quantifies the loss of learning model 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w} for data sample (𝒙n,i,yn,i)subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖(\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}). The goal of the FL system is to train an optimal global model 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\boldsymbol{w}^{*} that minimizes the global loss function F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F(\boldsymbol{w}), i.e.,

min𝒘⁡F​(𝒘)=∑n=1NDnD​Fn​(𝒘),subscript𝒘𝐹𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝐷𝑛𝐷subscript𝐹𝑛𝒘\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{w}}\;F(\boldsymbol{w})=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\frac{D_{n}}{D}F_{n}(\boldsymbol{w}), (1)

where Fn​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑛𝒘F_{n}(\boldsymbol{w}) is the local loss function of device n𝑛n, defined as

Fn​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑛𝒘\displaystyle F_{n}(\boldsymbol{w}) =1Dn​∑(𝒙n,i,yn,i)∈𝒟nf​(𝒘;𝒙n,i,yn,i).absent1subscript𝐷𝑛subscriptsubscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖subscript𝒟𝑛𝑓𝒘subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖\displaystyle=\frac{1}{D_{n}}\!\sum_{(\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i})\in\mathcal{D}_{n}}\!\!f(\boldsymbol{w};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}). (2)

To solve the learning problem (1) in a distributed manner, the FL system conducts the following three steps iteratively under the coordination of the server:

  • •

    The server schedules a subset of edge devices and broadcasts the global model to them.

  • •

    Each scheduled device computes its local gradient on its own local dataset by using the received learning model, and then uploads the local gradient to the server.

  • •

    The server aggregates local gradients of scheduled devices and then updates the global model.

Each iteration consisting of these three steps is called a time slot, indexed by t𝑡t. The whole training process continues until reaching a preset maxmimum number of time slots T𝑇T.

II-B Local Computation Model

At time slot t𝑡t, the server first schedules a subset of edge devices Ωt⊆[N]subscriptΩ𝑡delimited-[]𝑁\Omega_{t}\subseteq[N] and then broadcasts the current global model 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{t} to these selected devices. We assume that the server can broadcast the global model to edge devices without any error, due to its strong communication capability (e.g., large transmission power). Let βn,t∈{0,1}subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡01\beta_{n,t}\in\left\{0,1\right\} denote the scheduling indicator, with βn,t=1subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡1\beta_{n,t}=1 if device n𝑛n is scheduled at time slot t𝑡t, and βn,t=0subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡0\beta_{n,t}=0 otherwise. Then, we have Ωt={n|βn,t=1,n∈[N]}subscriptΩ𝑡conditional-set𝑛formulae-sequencesubscript𝛽𝑛𝑡1𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\Omega_{t}=\left\{n\,|\,\beta_{n,t}=1,n\in[N]\right\}. After receiving the global model 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{t}, each scheduled device n∈Ωt𝑛subscriptΩ𝑡n\in\Omega_{t} computes its local gradient 𝒈n,tsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡{\boldsymbol{g}}_{n,t} on its own local dataset as follows:

𝒈n,t=1Dn​∑(𝒙n,i,yn,i)∈𝒟n∇f​(𝒘t;𝒙n,i,yn,i).subscript𝒈𝑛𝑡1subscript𝐷𝑛subscriptsubscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖subscript𝒟𝑛∇𝑓subscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{g}}_{n,t}=\frac{1}{D_{n}}\!\sum_{(\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i})\in{\mathcal{D}}_{n}}\!\!\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w}_{t};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}). (3)

We consider a single-iteration gradient update in this work, and it can be extended to scenarios with multiple local iterations. The energy consumption for local computation of device n𝑛n at time slot t𝑡t is given by [20]

en,tcmp=In2​cn​Dn,superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛𝑡cmpsuperscriptsubscript𝐼𝑛2subscript𝑐𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛\displaystyle e_{n,t}^{\text{cmp}}=I_{n}^{2}c_{n}D_{n}, (4)

where Insubscript𝐼𝑛I_{n} is the CPU cycle frequency of device n𝑛n, and cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} is the number of CPU cycles required for device n𝑛n to process one data sample. Since the local computation energy en,tsubscript𝑒𝑛𝑡e_{n,t} is identical across time slots, we omit its subscript t𝑡t henceforth.

II-C Communication Model

After local computation, the scheduled edge devices send their local gradients to the server for global aggregation. For the uplink transmission, we adopt an orthogonal frequency division multiple access (OFDMA) technique, where each device occupies one resource block to upload its local gradient. We consider a non-trivial scenario where no more than R<N𝑅𝑁R<N devices can upload their local gradients at one time slot due to the limited bandwidth constraint. Thus, we have

∑n=1Nβn,t≤R,∀t.superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡𝑅for-all𝑡\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}\beta_{n,t}\leq R,\forall t. (5)

We assume that the uplink channel is block fading, i.e., the channel fading keeps constant during one time slot. Denote h~n,tsubscript~ℎ𝑛𝑡\tilde{h}_{n,t} as the uplink channel from device n𝑛n to the server at time slot t𝑡t with its channel gain hn,t=|h~n,t|subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript~ℎ𝑛𝑡h_{n,t}=|\tilde{h}_{n,t}|. The uplink rate of device n𝑛n at time slot t𝑡t is given by

rn,t=W​log2⁡(1+pn,t​hn,tN0​W),subscript𝑟𝑛𝑡𝑊subscript21subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑁0𝑊\displaystyle r_{n,t}=W\log_{2}\left(1+\frac{p_{n,t}h_{n,t}}{N_{0}W}\right), (6)

where pn,tsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t} is the transmission power of device n𝑛n at time slot t𝑡t, N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the noise power spectral density, and W𝑊W is the bandwidth for each resource block. Then, the communication energy consumption of device n𝑛n at time slot t𝑡t can be derived as

en,tcom=pn,t​snrn,t,superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛𝑡comsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑟𝑛𝑡\displaystyle e_{n,t}^{\text{com}}=\frac{p_{n,t}s_{n}}{r_{n,t}}, (7)

where snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} denotes the size of the n𝑛n-th device’s local gradient. The total energy consumption of device n𝑛n at time slot t𝑡t is given by

en,t=encmp+en,tcom.subscript𝑒𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛cmpsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛𝑡com\displaystyle e_{n,t}=e_{n}^{\text{cmp}}+e_{n,t}^{\text{com}}. (8)

In this paper, we assume that the local gradient of each device is transmitted as a single packet in the uplink. Due to the limited bandwidth and transmission power of edge devices, the packet error rate of uplink transmission cannot be ignored. Specifically, the packet error rate of the uplink transmission from device n𝑛n to the server at time slot t𝑡t is given by [21]

qn,t​(hn,t,pn,t)=1−exp⁡(−σ​N0​Wpn,t​hn,t),subscript𝑞𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡1𝜎subscript𝑁0𝑊subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡\displaystyle q_{n,t}(h_{n,t},p_{n,t})=1-\exp\left(-\frac{\sigma N_{0}W}{p_{n,t}h_{n,t}}\right), (9)

where σ𝜎\sigma is a constant parameter, namely, the waterfall threshold [21]. Let ζn,t∈{0,1}subscript𝜁𝑛𝑡01\zeta_{n,t}\in\left\{0,1\right\} denote the indicator of successful transmission, where ζn,t=0subscript𝜁𝑛𝑡0\zeta_{n,t}=0 indicates that the received local gradient of device n𝑛n at time slot t𝑡t is dropped due to the occurrence of packet error, and ζn,t=1subscript𝜁𝑛𝑡1\zeta_{n,t}=1 otherwise. Then, we have

ζn,t={1, with probability ​1−qn,t​(hn,t,pn,t);0, with probability ​qn,t​(hn,t,pn,t).subscript𝜁𝑛𝑡cases1 with probability 1subscript𝑞𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡0 with probability subscript𝑞𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\zeta_{n,t}=\begin{cases}1,&\text{ with probability }1-q_{n,t}(h_{n,t},p_{n,t});\\ 0,&\text{ with probability }q_{n,t}(h_{n,t},p_{n,t}).\end{cases} (10)

In the considered wireless FL system, the server employs successfully received local gradients from the scheduled devices to update the global model as follows:

𝒘t+1=𝒘t−η​∑n=1Nβn,t​ζn,t​𝒈n,t∑n=1Nβn,t​ζn,t,subscript𝒘𝑡1subscript𝒘𝑡𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡subscript𝜁𝑛𝑡subscript𝒈𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡subscript𝜁𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{w}_{t}-\eta\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\beta_{n,t}\zeta_{n,t}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{n,t}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\beta_{n,t}\zeta_{n,t}}, (11)

where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate. If all devices lack sufficient energy to upload local gradients to the server, or if all transmitted local gradients are lost, the server can utilize the previous global model, i.e., 𝒘t+1=𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡1subscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{w}_{t}.

II-D Energy Harvesting and Update Model

The limited battery capacity of edge devices poses significant challenges in sustaining the long-term operation of the wireless FL system without battery recharging. To address this issue, we consider that each edge device is equipped with an EH device to extract energy from the ambient environment. Furthermore, we assume that each device n𝑛n is equipped with a rechargeable battery with limited capacity bmaxsuperscript𝑏b^{\max}. The energy harvested at time slot t𝑡t is first stored in the battery and then available at the next time slot t+1𝑡1t+1. Let un,tsubscript𝑢𝑛𝑡u_{n,t} and bn,tsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t} denote the harvested energy and the energy level of device n𝑛n at time slot t𝑡t, respectively. The energy level dynamics of device n𝑛n over two adjacent time slots is given by

bn,t+1=min⁡{bn,t+un,t−en,t,bmax}.subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡1subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑢𝑛𝑡subscript𝑒𝑛𝑡superscript𝑏\displaystyle b_{n,t+1}=\min\{b_{n,t}+u_{n,t}-e_{n,t},b^{\max}\}. (12)

The energy consumption at each time slot cannot exceed the current remaining energy in the battery. Thus, the energy causality constraint is given by

0≤en,t≤bn,t,∀n,t.formulae-sequence0subscript𝑒𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡for-all𝑛𝑡\displaystyle 0\leq e_{n,t}\leq b_{n,t},\forall n,t. (13)

III Convergence Analysis and Problem Formulation

In this section, we first present convergence analysis for wireless FL with EH devices, deriving an upper bound for the optimality gap between the expected and optimal global loss. Then, we formulate a joint device scheduling and power control problem to minimize the expected optimality gap.

III-A Convergence Analysis

To facilitate the convergence analysis, we make the following standard assumptions, which are widely adopted in the literature on FL [8, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27].

Assumption 1.

(Smoothness) The local loss function Fn​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰F_{n}(\boldsymbol{w}) is L𝐿L-smooth. For any 𝐚,𝐛∈ℝd𝐚𝐛superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{a},\boldsymbol{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, n∈[N]𝑛delimited-[]𝑁n\in[N], we have

Fn​(𝒂)−Fn​(𝒃)≤∇Fn​(𝒃)𝖳​(𝒂−𝒃)+L2​‖𝒂−𝒃‖2.subscript𝐹𝑛𝒂subscript𝐹𝑛𝒃∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript𝒃𝖳𝒂𝒃𝐿2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒂𝒃2\displaystyle\begin{split}F_{n}(\boldsymbol{a})-F_{n}(\boldsymbol{b})\leq\nabla F_{n}(\boldsymbol{b})^{\mathsf{T}}(\boldsymbol{a}-\boldsymbol{b})+\frac{L}{2}\|\boldsymbol{a}-\boldsymbol{b}\|^{2}.\end{split} (14)
Assumption 2.

(Strong Convexity) The local loss function Fn​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰F_{n}(\boldsymbol{w}) is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex. For any 𝐚,𝐛∈ℝd𝐚𝐛superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{a},\boldsymbol{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, n∈[N]𝑛delimited-[]𝑁n\in[N], we have

Fn​(𝒂)−Fn​(𝒃)≥∇Fn​(𝒃)𝖳​(𝒂−𝒃)+μ2​‖𝒂−𝒃‖2.subscript𝐹𝑛𝒂subscript𝐹𝑛𝒃∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscript𝒃𝖳𝒂𝒃𝜇2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒂𝒃2\displaystyle\begin{split}F_{n}(\boldsymbol{a})-F_{n}(\boldsymbol{b})\geq\nabla F_{n}(\boldsymbol{b})^{\mathsf{T}}(\boldsymbol{a}-\boldsymbol{b})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\boldsymbol{a}-\boldsymbol{b}\|^{2}.\end{split} (15)
Assumption 3.

(Bounded Gradient) For any model 𝐰𝐰\boldsymbol{w} and data sample (𝐱n,i,yn,i)subscript𝐱𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖(\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}), there exists a constant ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0 satisfying

‖∇f​(𝒘;𝒙n,i,yn,i)‖2≤ρ.superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝒘subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖2𝜌\displaystyle\left\|\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i})\right\|^{2}\leq\rho. (16)

Based on the assumptions above, we characterize the upper bound of the expected optimality gap in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Given the initial model 𝐰1subscript𝐰1\boldsymbol{w}_{1}, for any device scheduling strategy {β1,t,…,βN,t}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑡…subscript𝛽𝑁𝑡𝑡1𝑇\{\beta_{1,t},\ldots,\beta_{N,t}\}_{t=1}^{T} and power control strategy {p1,t,…,pN,t}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑡…subscript𝑝𝑁𝑡𝑡1𝑇\{p_{1,t},\ldots,p_{N,t}\}_{t=1}^{T}, the optimality gap between the expected and optimal global loss is upper bounded by

𝔼​[F​(𝒘T+1)−F​(𝒘∗)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝒘𝑇1𝐹superscript𝒘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[F(\boldsymbol{w}_{T+1})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\right] (17)
≤\displaystyle\leq AT​(F​(𝒘1)−F​(𝒘∗))superscript𝐴𝑇𝐹subscript𝒘1𝐹superscript𝒘\displaystyle A^{T}\left(F(\boldsymbol{w}_{1})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\right)
+η​ρ2​N​∑t=1TAT−t​∑n=1N1−βn,t​(1−qn,t​(hn,t,pn,t))Dn,𝜂𝜌2𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁1subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡1subscript𝑞𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡subscript𝐷𝑛\displaystyle+\frac{\eta\rho}{2N}\sum_{t=1}^{T}A^{T-t}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\frac{1-\beta_{n,t}(1-q_{n,t}(h_{n,t},p_{n,t}))}{D_{n}},

where A=1−η​μ∈(0,1)𝐴1𝜂𝜇01A=1-\eta\mu\in(0,1) and the learning rate satisfies η≤min⁡{1L,1}𝜂1𝐿1\eta\leq\min\left\{\frac{1}{L},1\right\}.

Proof.

The proof is presented in Appendix A. ∎

Remark 1.

The first term on the right-hand-side (RHS) of (17) denotes the initial error caused by the gap between the initial model 𝐰1subscript𝐰1\boldsymbol{w}_{1} and the optimal model 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\boldsymbol{w}^{*}, while the second term corresponds to the error caused by partial device participation and packet drops. Specifically, the convergence rate of wireless FL can be improved by scheduling more devices and increasing their transmission power. However, in practical scenarios, both device scheduling and transmission power are constrained by the battery energy level. Thus, the transmission policy should be carefully designed to utilize the limited and uncertain harvested energy effectively.

III-B Problem Formulation

In this paper, we aim to optimize the device scheduling strategy {βn,t}subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡\{\beta_{n,t}\} and power control strategy {pn,t}subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡\{p_{n,t}\} to minimize the global loss F​(𝒘T+1)𝐹subscript𝒘𝑇1F(\boldsymbol{w}_{T+1}) after T𝑇T time slots. However, directly solving this problem is challenging since the global loss is hard to express in a closed form in terms of the transmission strategy. To address this issue, we approximate the actual global loss with its convergence bound derived in Theorem 1, and formulate an optimality gap minimization problem. Moreover, we ignore the first term on the RHS of (17) since it only relates to the initial error and converges to zero as T𝑇T increases. The formulated problem is given by

min{𝜷t,𝒑t}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜷𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝑡1𝑇min\displaystyle\underset{\{\boldsymbol{\beta}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\}_{t=1}^{T}}{\text{min}} η​ρ2​N​∑t=1TAT−t​∑n=1N1−βn,t​(1−qn,t​(hn,t,pn,t))Dn𝜂𝜌2𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁1subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡1subscript𝑞𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡subscript𝐷𝑛\displaystyle\;\frac{\eta\rho}{2N}\sum_{t=1}^{T}A^{T-t}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\frac{1-\beta_{n,t}(1-q_{n,t}(h_{n,t},p_{n,t}))}{D_{n}}
s.t. C1: ​∑n=1Nβn,t≤R,∀t,C1: superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡𝑅for-all𝑡\displaystyle~{}\text{C1:\;}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\beta_{n,t}\leq R,\forall t,
C2: ​0≤en,t≤bn,t,∀n,t,formulae-sequenceC2: 0subscript𝑒𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡for-all𝑛𝑡\displaystyle~{}\text{C2:\;\;}0\leq e_{n,t}\leq b_{n,t},\forall n,t, (18)

where 𝜷t={β1,t,…,βN,t}subscript𝜷𝑡subscript𝛽1𝑡…subscript𝛽𝑁𝑡\boldsymbol{\beta}_{t}=\{\beta_{1,t},\ldots,\beta_{N,t}\} and 𝒑t={p1,t,…,pN,t}subscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝑝1𝑡…subscript𝑝𝑁𝑡\boldsymbol{p}_{t}=\{p_{1,t},\ldots,p_{N,t}\}. Constraint C1 corresponds to the bandwidth constraint, while constraint C2 is the energy causality constraint. We remark that instead of adopting heuristic performance metrics (e.g., energy consumption and the number of scheduled devices), we provide a more reasonable objective function based on the convergence bound derived in Theorem 1.

We can further simplify problem (III-B) by substituting the device scheduling indicator βn,tsubscript𝛽𝑛𝑡\beta_{n,t} with the transmission power pn,tsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t}. The device n𝑛n is scheduled only when its transmit power pn,tsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t} is positive, i.e., βn,t=𝟙{pn,t>0}subscript𝛽𝑛𝑡subscript1subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡0\beta_{n,t}=\mathbbm{1}_{\left\{p_{n,t}>0\right\}}. Thus, problem (III-B) can be simplified as

min{𝒑t}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒑𝑡𝑡1𝑇min\displaystyle\underset{\{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\}_{t=1}^{T}}{\text{min}} η​ρ2​N​∑t=1T∑n=1NAT−t​qn,t​(hn,t,pn,t)Dn𝜂𝜌2𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡subscript𝑞𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡subscript𝐷𝑛\displaystyle~{}\frac{\eta\rho}{2N}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\frac{A^{T-t}q_{n,t}(h_{n,t},p_{n,t})}{D_{n}} (19)
s.t. C2,C2\displaystyle~{}\;\text{C2},
C3: ​∑n=1N𝟙{pn,t>0}≤R,∀t.C3: superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript1subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡0𝑅for-all𝑡\displaystyle~{}\;\text{C3: }\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mathbbm{1}_{\left\{p_{n,t}>0\right\}}\leq R,\forall t.

Constraint C3 is an equivalent transformation of constraint C1.

The reformulated problem (19) falls into the category of stochastic optimization problems, and it is hard to solve due to the inherent uncertainty of channel conditions and harvested energy. We note that the battery energy dynamics naturally exhibit the Markov property, and the first-order Markov chain sufficiently models slow fading channels. Motivated by these observations, we model problem (19) as a finite-horizon MDP and derive its optimal policy in Section IV.

IV MDP Formulation and Optimal Policy

In this section, we first propose an MDP framework for deriving the optimal transmission policy. We prove that the optimal policy can be computed offline using the Bellman equation. Then, we demonstrate that the optimal policy exhibits a monotone structure with respect to the battery and channel states.

IV-A MDP Formulation

To capture the temporal correlation of practical wireless channels, we adopt a finite-state Markov channel model, which has been extensively used to approximate various mathematical and experimental fading models (e.g., indoor channels, Rayleigh fading channels, and Rician fading channels) [28]. The channel is quantified into Nhsubscript𝑁ℎN_{h} states, with its corresponding channel gains quantified by ℋ={H1,H2,…,HNh}ℋsubscript𝐻1subscript𝐻2…subscript𝐻subscript𝑁ℎ\mathcal{H}=\left\{H_{1},H_{2},\ldots,H_{N_{h}}\right\}. Without loss of generality, we assume that Hi<Hi′subscript𝐻𝑖subscript𝐻superscript𝑖′H_{i}<H_{i^{\prime}}, for i<i′𝑖superscript𝑖′i<i^{\prime}. The transition probability matrix of the n𝑛n-th device’s channel is denoted by

Ψn=[ψn(1,1)⋯ψn(1,Nh)⋮⋱⋮ψn(Nh,1)⋯ψn(Nh,Nh)]subscriptΨ𝑛delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑛11⋯superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑛1subscript𝑁ℎ⋮⋱⋮superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑛subscript𝑁ℎ1⋯superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑛subscript𝑁ℎsubscript𝑁ℎ\displaystyle\Psi_{n}=\left[\begin{array}[]{lll}\psi_{n}^{(1,1)}&\cdots&\psi_{n}^{(1,N_{h})}\\ \vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ \psi_{n}^{(N_{h},1)}&\cdots&\psi_{n}^{(N_{h},N_{h})}\end{array}\right] (20)

with its (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j)-th entry ψn(i,j)=ℙ​(hn,t+1=Hj|hn,t=Hi)superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑛𝑖𝑗ℙsubscriptℎ𝑛𝑡1conditionalsubscript𝐻𝑗subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝐻𝑖\psi_{n}^{(i,j)}=\mathbb{P}(h_{n,t+1}=H_{j}|h_{n,t}=H_{i}). Moreover, the harvested energy un,tsubscript𝑢𝑛𝑡u_{n,t} is assumed to be i.i.d. across time slots according to some probability distribution ℙ​(Un)ℙsubscript𝑈𝑛\mathbb{P}(U_{n}), which depends on the external environment of device n𝑛n. The battery state of each device is also quantized into finite states, denoted by ℬℬ\mathcal{B}. Modeling the wireless channels and battery energy dynamics as homogeneous finite-state Markov chains, we formulate problem (19) as a finite-horizon MDP. The MDP is defined by the tuple (𝒮,𝒫,ℙ​(𝒉t+1,𝒃t+1|𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t),c​(𝒉t,𝒑t))𝒮𝒫ℙsubscript𝒉𝑡1conditionalsubscript𝒃𝑡1subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡\left(\mathcal{S},\mathcal{P},\mathbb{P}(\boldsymbol{h}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{b}_{t+1}|\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}),c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})\right), each component of which is described as follows:

  • •

    States: Denote sn,t=(hn,t,bn,t)subscript𝑠𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡s_{n,t}=(h_{n,t},b_{n,t}) as the state associated with device n𝑛n at time slot t𝑡t. The state space 𝒮nsubscript𝒮𝑛\mathcal{S}_{n} of device n𝑛n is a composite space with 𝒮n=ℋ×ℬsubscript𝒮𝑛ℋℬ\mathcal{S}_{n}=\mathcal{H}\times\mathcal{B}, where ×\times denotes the Cartesian product. The state of the entire system at time slot t𝑡t is expressed as st=(s1,t,…,sN,t)∈𝒮subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑠1𝑡…subscript𝑠𝑁𝑡𝒮s_{t}=(s_{1,t},\ldots,s_{N,t})\in\mathcal{S}, where 𝒮=𝒮1×…×𝒮N=ℋN×ℬN𝒮subscript𝒮1…subscript𝒮𝑁superscriptℋ𝑁superscriptℬ𝑁\mathcal{S}=\mathcal{S}_{1}\times\ldots\times\mathcal{S}_{N}=\mathcal{H}^{N}\times\mathcal{B}^{N} is the state space of the entire system.

  • •

    Actions: In practice, wireless edge devices can be programmed to have a finite set of transmission power levels. Thus, we assume each device n𝑛n discretely selects its transmission power pn,t∈𝒫nsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡subscript𝒫𝑛p_{n,t}\in\mathcal{P}_{n}, where 𝒫nsubscript𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}_{n} is the finite action space of device n𝑛n. If pn,t=0subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡0p_{n,t}=0, device n𝑛n remains idle at time slot t𝑡t. The action space of the whole system is given by 𝒫=𝒫1×…×𝒫N𝒫subscript𝒫1…subscript𝒫𝑁\mathcal{P}=\mathcal{P}_{1}\times\ldots\times\mathcal{P}_{N}.

    =\displaystyle= ∏n=1Nℙ​(hn,t+1,bn,t+1|hn,t,bn,t,pn,t)superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑛1𝑁ℙsubscriptℎ𝑛𝑡1conditionalsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡1subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\prod_{n=1}^{N}\mathbb{P}(h_{n,t+1},b_{n,t+1}|h_{n,t},b_{n,t},p_{n,t})
    =\displaystyle= ∏n=1Nℙ​(hn,t+1|hn,t)​ℙ​(bn,t+1|hn,t,bn,t,pn,t).superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑛1𝑁ℙconditionalsubscriptℎ𝑛𝑡1subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡ℙconditionalsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡1subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\prod_{n=1}^{N}\mathbb{P}(h_{n,t+1}|h_{n,t})\mathbb{P}(b_{n,t+1}|h_{n,t},b_{n,t},p_{n,t}).

    Considering the battery dynamics shown in (12), the first-order conditional probability of the process bn,tsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t} is given by

    ℙ​(bn,t+1|hn,t,bn,t,pn,t)ℙconditionalsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡1subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{P}(b_{n,t+1}|h_{n,t},b_{n,t},p_{n,t}){}{} (22)

    One-Step Cost: Inspired by the objective function in problem (19), we consider a cost function that quantifies the penalty associated with packet drops and partial device participation. Specifically, the one-step cost at time slot t𝑡t is defined as

    c​(𝒉t,𝒑t)=𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡absent\displaystyle c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})= ∑n=1Ncn​(hn,t,pn,t),superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑐𝑛subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}c_{n}({h}_{n,t},{p}_{n,t}), (23)

The objective of the MDP is to derive the optimal policy that minimizes the expected cumulative cost. The policy π={πt:𝒮→𝒫}t=1T𝜋superscriptsubscriptconditional-setsubscript𝜋𝑡→𝒮𝒫𝑡1𝑇\pi=\{\pi_{t}:\mathcal{S}\rightarrow\mathcal{P}\}_{t=1}^{T} determines the transmission power 𝒑tsubscript𝒑𝑡\boldsymbol{p}_{t} based on the state (𝒉t,𝒃t)subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}) at each time slot t𝑡t. For a given policy π𝜋\pi, we define the expected cumulative cost as

J​(π)=𝔼π​[∑t=1TAT−t​c​(𝒉t,𝒑t)|𝒉1,𝒃1],𝐽𝜋subscript𝔼𝜋delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝒉1subscript𝒃1\displaystyle J(\pi)=\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\sum_{t=1}^{T}A^{T-t}c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})|\boldsymbol{h}_{1},\boldsymbol{b}_{1}\right], (24)

where (𝒉1,𝒃1)subscript𝒉1subscript𝒃1(\boldsymbol{h}_{1},\boldsymbol{b}_{1}) is the initial state. By defining the expected cumulative cost in this way, problem (19) is reformulated as the following problem that computes the optimal policy π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} to minimize the expected optimality gap.

Problem 1.

(Optimality Gap Minimization Problem)

π∗=argmin𝜋superscript𝜋𝜋argmin\displaystyle\pi^{*}=\underset{\pi}{\textup{argmin}}{} J​(π)𝐽𝜋\displaystyle J(\pi) (25)
s.t. C2 and C3.C2 and C3\displaystyle\textup{C2 and C3}.

We note that the objective function in Problem 1 is a weighted sum of costs c​(𝒉t,𝒑t)𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}), where the weight AT−tsuperscript𝐴𝑇𝑡A^{T-t} increases with time slot t𝑡t. This formulation differs from the standard discounted MDPs, which apply a discount factor typically less than 111 to diminish the importance of future costs over time. To address this unique inversion of discounting, we introduce a modified Bellman equation in the following subsection to compute the optimal policy for Problem 1.

IV-B Optimal Policy

In this subsection, we show that the optimal policy can be derived offline according to the Bellman equation. Moreover, we prove that the optimal policy possesses a monotone structure with respect to the battery and channel states.

We first derive the optimal policy for Problem 1 in the following theorem.

Theorem 2.

Given the initial state (𝐡1,𝐛1)subscript𝐡1subscript𝐛1(\boldsymbol{h}_{1},\boldsymbol{b}_{1}), the optimal value V1​(𝐡1,𝐛1)subscript𝑉1subscript𝐡1subscript𝐛1V_{1}(\boldsymbol{h}_{1},\boldsymbol{b}_{1}) of the objective in Problem 1 can be computed recursively according to the Bellman equation. Specifically, for 1≤t≤T−11𝑡𝑇11\leq t\leq T-1, we have

Vt​(𝒉t,𝒃t)subscript𝑉𝑡subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡\displaystyle V_{t}(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}) (26)
=\displaystyle= min𝒑t∈𝒫t⁡{AT−t​c​(𝒉t,𝒑t)+𝔼​[Vt+1​(𝒉t+1,𝒃t+1)|𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t]},subscriptsubscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝒫𝑡superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝑉𝑡1subscript𝒉𝑡1subscript𝒃𝑡1subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}\left\{A^{T-t}c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})+\mathbb{E}\left[V_{t+1}(\boldsymbol{h}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{b}_{t+1})|\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\right]\right\},

and the terminal condition is given by

VT​(𝒉T,𝒃T)=subscript𝑉𝑇subscript𝒉𝑇subscript𝒃𝑇absent\displaystyle V_{T}(\boldsymbol{h}_{T},\boldsymbol{b}_{T})= min𝒑T∈𝒫T⁡{c​(𝒉T,𝒑T)},subscriptsubscript𝒑𝑇subscript𝒫𝑇𝑐subscript𝒉𝑇subscript𝒑𝑇\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{p}_{T}\in\mathcal{P}_{T}}\left\{c(\boldsymbol{h}_{T},\boldsymbol{p}_{T})\right\}, (27)

where 𝒫t={𝐩t∈𝒫:∑n𝟙{pn,t>0}≤R,0≤en,t≤bn,t,∀n}subscript𝒫𝑡conditional-setsubscript𝐩𝑡𝒫formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencesubscript𝑛subscript1subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡0𝑅0subscript𝑒𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡for-all𝑛\mathcal{P}_{t}=\left\{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}\!:\!\sum_{n}\!\mathbbm{1}_{\left\{p_{n,t}>0\right\}}\!\leq\!R,0\leq e_{n,t}\leq b_{n,t},\forall n\right\} denotes the feasible set of transmission power actions at time slot t𝑡t.

Proof.

The proof is presented in Appendix B. ∎

After solving the Bellman equation through backward induction, the optimal transmission power 𝒑t∗superscriptsubscript𝒑𝑡\boldsymbol{p}_{t}^{*} can be derived as follows: ∀1≤t≤T−1,for-all1𝑡𝑇1\forall 1\leq t\leq T-1,

𝒑t∗=subscriptsuperscript𝒑𝑡absent\displaystyle\boldsymbol{p}^{*}_{t}\!= arg​min𝒑t∈𝒫t⁡{AT−t​c​(𝒉t,𝒑t)+𝔼​[Vt+1​(𝒉t+1,𝒃t+1)|𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t]},subscriptargminsubscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝒫𝑡superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝑉𝑡1subscript𝒉𝑡1subscript𝒃𝑡1subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡\displaystyle\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}\!\left\{\!A^{T-t}c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})\!+\!\mathbb{E}\!\left[V_{t+1}\!(\boldsymbol{h}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{b}_{t+1})|\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\right]\right\}\!\!, (28)

and

𝒑T∗=subscriptsuperscript𝒑𝑇absent\displaystyle\boldsymbol{p}^{*}_{T}= arg​min𝒑T∈𝒫T⁡{c​(𝒉T,𝒑T)}.subscriptargminsubscript𝒑𝑇subscript𝒫𝑇𝑐subscript𝒉𝑇subscript𝒑𝑇\displaystyle\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}_{T}\in\mathcal{P}_{T}}\left\{c(\boldsymbol{h}_{T},\boldsymbol{p}_{T})\right\}. (29)

We remark that the optimal policy for Problem 1 can only be obtained numerically according to the Bellman equation, and there is no closed form solution.

Next, we give some insights into the optimal policy by studying its monotone structure. To facilitate analysis, we first prove the convexity of the value function Vt​(𝒉t,𝒃t)subscript𝑉𝑡subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡V_{t}(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}) with respect to the battery state in the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

Given any fixed 𝐡tsubscript𝐡𝑡\boldsymbol{h}_{t}, the value function Vt​(𝐡t,𝐛t)subscript𝑉𝑡subscript𝐡𝑡subscript𝐛𝑡V_{t}(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}) is convex in 𝐛tsubscript𝐛𝑡\boldsymbol{b}_{t} for 1≤t≤T1𝑡𝑇1\leq t\leq T.

Proof.

The proof is presented in Appendix C. ∎

By applying Lemma 1, we further show that the optimal policy possesses a monotone structure with respect to the battery state in the following theorem.

Theorem 3.

Given any fixed 𝐡tsubscript𝐡𝑡\boldsymbol{h}_{t} and {bm,t,m∈[N]\n}subscript𝑏𝑚𝑡𝑚\delimited-[]𝑁𝑛\left\{b_{m,t},m\in[N]\backslash n\right\}, the optimal transmission power pn,t∗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t}^{*} of device n𝑛n at time slot t𝑡t is non-decreasing in its current battery level bn,tsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t} for 1≤t≤T1𝑡𝑇1\leq t\leq T.

Proof.

It is obvious that at the final time slot T𝑇T, pn,T∗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑇p_{n,T}^{*} is non-decreasing in bn,Tsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑇b_{n,T}, since all the remaining energy should be used up in the final time slot. Then, we prove that pn,t∗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t}^{*} is non-decreasing in bn,tsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t} for 1≤t≤T−11𝑡𝑇11\leq t\leq T-1. We first define the RHS of (28) with fixed 𝒉tsubscript𝒉𝑡\boldsymbol{h}_{t} and {bm,t,m∈[N]\n}subscript𝑏𝑚𝑡𝑚\delimited-[]𝑁𝑛\left\{b_{m,t},m\in[N]\backslash n\right\} as follows:

Zn,t​(bn,t,pn,t)subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡\displaystyle Z_{n,t}(b_{n,t},p_{n,t}) (30)
=AT−t​c​(𝒉t,𝒑t)+𝔼​[Vt+1​(𝒉t+1,𝒃t+1)|𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t].absentsuperscript𝐴𝑇𝑡𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝑉𝑡1subscript𝒉𝑡1subscript𝒃𝑡1subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡\displaystyle=A^{T-t}c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})+\mathbb{E}\left[V_{t+1}(\boldsymbol{h}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{b}_{t+1})|\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\right].

Then, we introduce a definition, namely, submodularity. A function f:𝒳×𝒴→ℛ:𝑓→𝒳𝒴ℛf:\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is a submodular function if it satisfies the following condition:

f​(x+,y+)+f​(x−,y−)≤f​(x+,y−)+f​(x−,y+),𝑓superscript𝑥superscript𝑦𝑓superscript𝑥superscript𝑦𝑓superscript𝑥superscript𝑦𝑓superscript𝑥superscript𝑦\displaystyle f(x^{+},y^{+})+f(x^{-},y^{-})\leq f(x^{+},y^{-})+f(x^{-},y^{+}), (31)

where x+≥x−superscript𝑥superscript𝑥x^{+}\geq x^{-} and y+≥y−superscript𝑦superscript𝑦y^{+}\geq y^{-}.

To show that pn,t∗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t}^{*} is non-decreasing in bn,tsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t}, it is sufficient to show that Zn,t​(bn,t,pn,t)subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡Z_{n,t}(b_{n,t},p_{n,t}) is submodular in (bn,t,pn,t)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡(b_{n,t},p_{n,t}) [29]. Here we provide some intuitive explanations. According to the submodularity of Zn,t​(bn,t,pn,t)subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡Z_{n,t}(b_{n,t},p_{n,t}), we have that if Zn,t​(bn,t−,pn,t+)≤Zn,t​(bn,t−,pn,t−)subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡Z_{n,t}(b_{n,t}^{-},p_{n,t}^{+})\leq Z_{n,t}(b_{n,t}^{-},p_{n,t}^{-}), then Zn,t​(bn,t+,pn,t+)≤Zn,t​(bn,t+,pn,t−)subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡Z_{n,t}(b_{n,t}^{+},p_{n,t}^{+})\leq Z_{n,t}(b_{n,t}^{+},p_{n,t}^{-}), where bn,t+≥bn,t−superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t}^{+}\geq b_{n,t}^{-} and pn,t+≥pn,t−superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t}^{+}\geq p_{n,t}^{-}. This implies that if using pn,t+superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t}^{+} leads to a lower cost than using pn,t−superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t}^{-} when the battery level is bn,t−superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t}^{-}, then it is the same when the battery level is bn,t+superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t}^{+}, which indicates the transmission power pn,tsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t} is non-decreasing in bn,tsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t}.

It is evident that the first term of Zn,t​(bn,t,pn,t)subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡Z_{n,t}(b_{n,t},p_{n,t}), i.e., AT−t​c​(𝒉t,𝒑t)superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡A^{T-t}c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}), is submodular in (bn,t,pn,t)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡(b_{n,t},p_{n,t}) since it is independent of bn,tsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t}. Then, define 𝒙t=𝒃t−𝒆tsubscript𝒙𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒆𝑡\boldsymbol{x}_{t}=\boldsymbol{b}_{t}-\boldsymbol{e}_{t} with its n𝑛n-th entry xn,t=bn,t−en,tsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑒𝑛𝑡x_{n,t}={b}_{n,t}-{e}_{n,t}. Given fixed {bm,t,m∈[N]\n}subscript𝑏𝑚𝑡𝑚\delimited-[]𝑁𝑛\left\{b_{m,t},m\in[N]\backslash n\right\}, we denote the second term of Zn,t​(bn,t,pn,t)subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡Z_{n,t}(b_{n,t},p_{n,t}) as

Kn,t(xn,t)=𝔼[Vt+1(𝒉t+1,min{𝒙t+𝒖t,𝒃max}|𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t],\displaystyle K_{n,t}(x_{n,t})=\mathbb{E}\left[V_{t+1}(\boldsymbol{h}_{t+1},\min\{\boldsymbol{x}_{t}+\boldsymbol{u}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}^{\max}\}|\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\right], (32)

where xm,tsubscript𝑥𝑚𝑡x_{m,t} is fixed for m∈[N]\n𝑚\delimited-[]𝑁𝑛m\in[N]\backslash n. According to the convexity of Vt​(𝒉t,𝒃t)subscript𝑉𝑡subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡V_{t}(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}) in 𝒃tsubscript𝒃𝑡\boldsymbol{b}_{t}, as shown in Lemma 1, we have

Kn,t​(xn,t+ϵ)−Kn,t​(xn,t)≤Kn,t​(xn,t′+ϵ)−Kn,t​(xn,t′),subscript𝐾𝑛𝑡subscript𝑥𝑛𝑡italic-ϵsubscript𝐾𝑛𝑡subscript𝑥𝑛𝑡subscript𝐾𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑡′italic-ϵsubscript𝐾𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑡′\displaystyle K_{n,t}(x_{n,t}+\epsilon)-K_{n,t}(x_{n,t})\leq K_{n,t}(x_{n,t}^{\prime}+\epsilon)-K_{n,t}(x_{n,t}^{\prime}), (33)

Then, we can obtain that the second term of Zn,t​(bn,t,pn,t)subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡Z_{n,t}(b_{n,t},p_{n,t}) is also submodular in (bn,t,pn,t)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡(b_{n,t},p_{n,t}). Thus, pn,t∗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t}^{*} is non-decreasing in bn,tsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑡b_{n,t}. ∎

Next, we demonstrate that the optimal policy also exhibits a monotone structure with respect to the channel state. To this end, we first make the following assumption.

Assumption 4.

(The stochastic monotonicity of the channel transition probability matrix) The channel transition probability matrix ΨnsubscriptΨ𝑛\Psi_{n}, ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N] is stochastic monotone. For 1≤i≤i′≤Nh1𝑖superscript𝑖′subscript𝑁ℎ1\leq i\leq i^{\prime}\leq N_{h}, 1≤k≤Nh1𝑘subscript𝑁ℎ1\leq k\leq N_{h}, we have

∑j=kNhψn(i′,j)≥∑j=kNhψn(i,j).superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑘subscript𝑁ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝜓𝑛superscript𝑖′𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑘subscript𝑁ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝜓𝑛𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\begin{split}\sum_{j=k}^{N_{h}}\psi_{n}^{(i^{\prime},j)}\geq\sum_{j=k}^{N_{h}}\psi_{n}^{(i,j)}.\end{split} (34)

Assumption 4 is widely used in the Markov modeling of various fading channels, such as Rayleigh and Rician fading channels [28]. It allows for an intuitive interpretation: better channel quality at the current time slot indicates a higher probability of maintaining better channel quality at the next time slot. Based on Assumption 4, we prove that the optimal policy possesses a monotone structure with respect to the channel state in the following theorem.

Theorem 4.

Given any fixed 𝐛tsubscript𝐛𝑡\boldsymbol{b}_{t} and {hm,t,m∈[N]\n}subscriptℎ𝑚𝑡𝑚\delimited-[]𝑁𝑛\left\{h_{m,t},m\in[N]\backslash n\right\}, if Assumption 4 holds, the optimal transmission power pn,t∗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡p_{n,t}^{*} of device n𝑛n at time slot t𝑡t is non-increasing in its current channel state hn,tsubscriptℎ𝑛𝑡h_{n,t} for 1≤t≤T1𝑡𝑇1\leq t\leq T.

Proof.

The proof is presented in Appendix D. ∎

Fig. 2 demonstrates the monotone structure for the optimal policy of one typical device. The benefits for the monotone structure are twofold. First, it reduces the storage space for online implementation, as only the boundary states used for switching transmission power need to be stored. Second, the monotone structure can reduce the computational overhead for solving the Bellman equation. According to the monotone structure, the standard value iteration algorithm can be modified as follows. At time slot t𝑡t, within the defined state space [𝒉min,𝒉max]×[𝒃min,𝒃max]subscript𝒉minsubscript𝒉maxsubscript𝒃minsubscript𝒃max[\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{min}},\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{max}}]\times[\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{min}},\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{max}}], we first compute the optimal actions at the corners, i.e., 𝒑t∗​(𝒉min,𝒃max)superscriptsubscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝒉minsubscript𝒃max\boldsymbol{p}_{t}^{*}(\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{min}},\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{max}}) and 𝒑t∗​(𝒉max,𝒃min)superscriptsubscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝒉maxsubscript𝒃min\boldsymbol{p}_{t}^{*}(\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{max}},\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{min}}), according to the Bellman equation. Then, we check whether there exists an action 𝒑t#subscriptsuperscript𝒑#𝑡\boldsymbol{p}^{\#}_{t} such that

𝒑t#=𝒑t∗​(𝒉min,𝒃max)=𝒑t∗​(𝒉max,𝒃min).subscriptsuperscript𝒑#𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝒉minsubscript𝒃maxsuperscriptsubscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝒉maxsubscript𝒃min\displaystyle\boldsymbol{p}^{\#}_{t}=\boldsymbol{p}_{t}^{*}(\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{min}},\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{max}})=\boldsymbol{p}_{t}^{*}(\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{max}},\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{min}}). (35)

If such an action 𝒑t#subscriptsuperscript𝒑#𝑡\boldsymbol{p}^{\#}_{t} exists, it can be determined as the optimal action for the entire region, and we update the value function for this region as follows:

Vt​(𝒉t,𝒃t)=AT−t​c​(𝒉t,𝒑t#)+𝔼​[Vt+1​(𝒉t+1,𝒃t+1)|𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t#],subscript𝑉𝑡subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒑#𝑡𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝑉𝑡1subscript𝒉𝑡1subscript𝒃𝑡1subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒑#𝑡\displaystyle V_{t}(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t})\!=\!A^{T-t}c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}^{\#}_{t})\!+\!\mathbb{E}\!\left[\!V_{t+1}(\boldsymbol{h}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{b}_{t+1})|\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}^{\#}_{t}\!\right]\!\!, (36)
∀𝒉t∈[𝒉min,𝒉max],𝒃t∈[𝒃min,𝒃max].formulae-sequencefor-allsubscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒉minsubscript𝒉maxsubscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒃minsubscript𝒃max\displaystyle\forall\boldsymbol{h}_{t}\in[\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{min}},\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{max}}],\boldsymbol{b}_{t}\in[\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{min}},\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{max}}].

If such a 𝒑t#subscriptsuperscript𝒑#𝑡\boldsymbol{p}^{\#}_{t} does not exist, we calculate the midpoints 𝒉mid=⌊𝒉min+𝒉max2⌋subscript𝒉midsubscript𝒉minsubscript𝒉max2\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{mid}}=\lfloor\frac{\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{min}}+\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{max}}}{2}\rfloor and 𝒃mid=⌊𝒃min+𝒃max2⌋subscript𝒃midsubscript𝒃minsubscript𝒃max2\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{mid}}=\lfloor\frac{\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{min}}+\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{max}}}{2}\rfloor, and we split the current region into four quadrants: [𝒉min,𝒉mid]×[𝒃min,𝒃mid]subscript𝒉minsubscript𝒉midsubscript𝒃minsubscript𝒃mid[\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{min}},\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{mid}}]\times[\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{min}},\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{mid}}], [𝒉min,𝒉mid]×[𝒃mid,𝒃max]subscript𝒉minsubscript𝒉midsubscript𝒃midsubscript𝒃max[\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{min}},\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{mid}}]\times[\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{mid}},\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{max}}], [𝒉mid,𝒉max]×[𝒃min,𝒃mid]subscript𝒉midsubscript𝒉maxsubscript𝒃minsubscript𝒃mid[\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{mid}},\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{max}}]\times[\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{min}},\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{mid}}], and [𝒉mid,𝒉max]×[𝒃mid,𝒃max]subscript𝒉midsubscript𝒉maxsubscript𝒃midsubscript𝒃max[\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{mid}},\boldsymbol{h}_{\textup{max}}]\times[\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{mid}},\boldsymbol{b}_{\textup{max}}]. Then, we apply the same checking and subdivision process recursively to each of these subregions. The recursion terminates when the optimal actions for all states are determined. We note that equation (36) avoids the brute-force search over the action space 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}, thereby significantly reducing the computational complexity. According to Theorems 3 and 4, the modified algorithm converges to the optimal policy as the standard value iteration algorithm does.

Although the monotone structure can reduce the computational complexity, computing the optimal transmission policy of multiple devices still remains challenging. Specifically, the computational complexity for deriving the optimal policy is 𝒪​(|𝒮|2​|𝒫|)𝒪superscript𝒮2𝒫\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{S}|^{2}|\mathcal{P}|) [30], where both the state space 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} and the action space 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} grow exponentially with the number of devices N𝑁N. Thus, the computational complexity also increases exponentially in N𝑁N. To address the curse of dimensionality, in Section V, we trade off optimality for complexity and develop an asymptotically optimal policy, the computational complexity of which increases only linearly with N𝑁N.

V Asymptotically Optimal Policy: Relax-and-Truncate Approach

In this section, we first develop a low-complexity algorithm, termed the relax-and-truncate approach, whose computational complexity increases only linearly with the number of devices, N𝑁N. Then, we prove that the proposed algorithm is asymptotically optimal as N𝑁N increases.

V-A Device Level Decomposition

We start by observing that Problem 1 is intractable due to constraint C3, which couples the transmission power actions {pn,t,n∈[N]}subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\left\{p_{n,t},n\in[N]\right\}, resulting in the exponential complexity. To address this issue, we relax the hard constraint C3 into a time-average constraint. First, we define the time-average number of scheduled devices under a policy π𝜋\pi as

R​(π)=𝑅𝜋absent\displaystyle R(\pi)= 𝔼π​[1T​∑t=1T∑n=1N𝟙{pn,t>0}].subscript𝔼𝜋delimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript1subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡0\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mathbbm{1}_{\left\{p_{n,t}>0\right\}}\right]. (37)

Then, we formulate the relaxed problem as follows.

Problem 2.

(Relaxed Optimality Gap Minimization Problem)

π¯∗=argmin𝜋superscript¯𝜋𝜋argmin\displaystyle\overline{\pi}^{*}=\underset{\pi}{\textup{argmin}}{}{} J​(π)𝐽𝜋\displaystyle J(\pi) (38)
s.t. C2,C2\displaystyle\textup{C2},
C3¯:R​(π)≤R.:¯C3𝑅𝜋𝑅\displaystyle\overline{\textup{C3}}:R(\pi)\leq R.

The relaxed bandwidth constraint C3¯¯C3\overline{\textup{C3}} allows more than R𝑅R devices to upload local gradients at certain time slots, provided that the time-average bandwidth constraint is satisfied over all time slots. The optimal policy for Problem 2 is referred to as the optimal relaxed policy π¯∗superscript¯𝜋\overline{\pi}^{*} hereinafter.

The relaxed constraint C3¯¯C3\overline{\textup{C3}} in Problem 2 still couples the power actions of all devices. To tackle this issue, we adopt a device level decomposition by using the Lagrange approach [31]. Specifically, we introduce a Lagrange multiplier λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0 and define the Lagrangian associated with Problem 2 as

ℒ​(π,λ)ℒ𝜋𝜆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\pi,\lambda) (39)
=\displaystyle= 𝔼π​[∑t=1T(AT−t​c​(𝒉t,𝒑t)+λ​(∑n=1N𝟙{pn,t>0}−R))].subscript𝔼𝜋delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript1subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡0𝑅\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(A^{T-t}c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})+\lambda\left(\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mathbbm{1}_{\left\{p_{n,t}>0\right\}}-R\right)\right)\right].

The Lagrange multiplier λ𝜆\lambda can be interpreted as the cost of scheduling one device at a time slot. For a given λ𝜆\lambda, we define the Lagrange dual function as

ℒ∗​(λ)=minπsuperscriptℒ𝜆subscript𝜋\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{*}(\lambda)=\min_{\pi}{} ℒ​(π,λ)ℒ𝜋𝜆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\pi,\lambda) (40)
s.t. C2.C2\displaystyle\textup{C2}.

A policy that achieves ℒ∗​(λ)superscriptℒ𝜆\mathcal{L}^{*}(\lambda) is called the λ𝜆\lambda-optimal policy π¯λsubscript¯𝜋𝜆\overline{\pi}_{\lambda}.

Note that the dimension of the state space 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} is finite and the one-step cost is bounded below, i.e., c​(𝒉,𝒑)≥0,∀𝒉,𝒑𝑐𝒉𝒑0for-all𝒉𝒑c(\boldsymbol{h},\boldsymbol{p})\geq 0,\forall\boldsymbol{h},\boldsymbol{p}. Under these conditions, there exists an optimal Lagrange multiplier λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} such that J​(π¯∗)=ℒ∗​(λ∗)𝐽superscript¯𝜋superscriptℒsuperscript𝜆J(\overline{\pi}^{*})=\mathcal{L}^{*}(\lambda^{*}) and λ∗​(R​(π¯λ∗)−R)=0superscript𝜆𝑅subscript¯𝜋superscript𝜆𝑅0\lambda^{*}\left(R(\overline{\pi}_{\lambda^{*}})-R\right)=0 [31, Theorem 12.8]. Thus, the optimal relaxed policy π¯∗superscript¯𝜋\overline{\pi}^{*} can be computed by using a two-stage iterative algorithm: 1) For a given λ𝜆\lambda, we find the λ𝜆\lambda-optimal policy; 2) we update λ𝜆\lambda by applying a bisection method. These two steps are detailed in the following.

V-A1 Optimal Policy for a Fixed Lagrange Multiplier

Given a fixed λ𝜆\lambda, the problem of finding the λ𝜆\lambda-optimal policy π¯λsubscript¯𝜋𝜆\overline{\pi}_{\lambda} is separable across devices and can be decoupled into N𝑁N per-device subproblems. Specifically, the Lagrangian in (39) can be expressed equivalently as ℒ​(π,λ)=∑n=1Nℒn​(πn,λ)ℒ𝜋𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptℒ𝑛subscript𝜋𝑛𝜆\mathcal{L}(\pi,\lambda)=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mathcal{L}_{n}(\pi_{n},\lambda), where

ℒn​(πn,λ)subscriptℒ𝑛subscript𝜋𝑛𝜆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{n}(\pi_{n},\lambda) (41)
=\displaystyle= 𝔼πn​[∑t=1T(AT−t​cn​(hn,t,pn,t)+λ​𝟙{pn,t>0}−λ​RN)],subscript𝔼subscript𝜋𝑛delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡subscript𝑐𝑛subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡𝜆subscript1subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡0𝜆𝑅𝑁\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\pi_{n}}\left[\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(A^{T-t}c_{n}({h}_{n,t},{p}_{n,t})+\lambda\mathbbm{1}_{\left\{p_{n,t}>0\right\}}-\frac{\lambda R}{N}\right)\right],

and πn={πn,t:𝒮n→𝒫n}t=1Tsubscript𝜋𝑛superscriptsubscriptconditional-setsubscript𝜋𝑛𝑡→subscript𝒮𝑛subscript𝒫𝑛𝑡1𝑇\pi_{n}=\{\pi_{n,t}:\mathcal{S}_{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{P}_{n}\}_{t=1}^{T} is the policy of device n𝑛n. Then, the problem of finding π¯λsubscript¯𝜋𝜆\overline{\pi}_{\lambda} reduces to finding N𝑁N per-device λ𝜆\lambda-optimal policies π¯n,λsubscript¯𝜋𝑛𝜆\overline{\pi}_{n,\lambda} as follows.

Problem 3.

(Decoupled Optimality Gap Minimization)

π¯n,λ=argminπnsubscript¯𝜋𝑛𝜆subscript𝜋𝑛argmin\displaystyle\overline{\pi}_{n,\lambda}=\underset{\pi_{n}}{\textup{argmin}}{}{} ℒn​(πn,λ)subscriptℒ𝑛subscript𝜋𝑛𝜆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{n}(\pi_{n},\lambda) (42)
s.t. C2.C2\displaystyle\textup{C2}.

The decoupled Problem 3 for each device n𝑛n can be modeled as an MDP and solved by value iteration or policy iteration algorithms.

V-A2 Determination of the Optimal Lagrange Multiplier

According to [32, Lemma 3.1], R​(π¯λ)𝑅subscript¯𝜋𝜆R(\overline{\pi}_{\lambda}) decreases as λ𝜆\lambda increases. Intuitively, the Lagrange multiplier λ𝜆\lambda can be interpreted as the cost of scheduling one device; thus, increasing λ𝜆\lambda imposes a greater penalty on the scheduling cost in the Lagrangian. Our goal is to identify the smallest value of λ𝜆\lambda that satisfies the relaxed bandwidth constraint C3¯¯C3\overline{\textup{C3}}. Formally, the optimal Lagrange multiplier is defined as

λ∗=inf{λ≥0:R​(π¯λ)≤R}.superscript𝜆infimumconditional-set𝜆0𝑅subscript¯𝜋𝜆𝑅\displaystyle\lambda^{*}=\inf\left\{\lambda\geq 0:R(\overline{\pi}_{\lambda})\leq R\right\}. (43)

To search for the optimal Lagrange multiplier λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}, we apply the bisection method, which exploits the monotonicity of R​(π¯λ)𝑅subscript¯𝜋𝜆R(\overline{\pi}_{\lambda}) with respect to λ𝜆\lambda. We initialize λ−=0superscript𝜆0\lambda^{-}=0 and λ+superscript𝜆\lambda^{+} as a sufficiently large number such that R​(π¯λ+)<R𝑅subscript¯𝜋superscript𝜆𝑅R(\overline{\pi}_{\lambda^{+}})<R. The algorithm terminates when λ+−λ−<ϵsuperscript𝜆superscript𝜆italic-ϵ\lambda^{+}-\lambda^{-}<\epsilon, where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is a sufficiently small constant. We summarize the complete procedure for deriving the optimal relaxed policy π¯∗superscript¯𝜋\overline{\pi}^{*} in Algorithm 1.

Remark 2.

By employing the Lagrange approach, solving the relaxed Problem 2 is reduced to solving N𝑁N subproblems (i.e. Problem 3). It is worth noting that, in this manner, the computational complexity of finding the optimal relaxed policy π¯∗superscript¯𝜋\overline{\pi}^{*} increases only linearly with the number of devices N𝑁N, whereas the computational complexity of computing the optimal policy π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} grows exponentially with N𝑁N.

V-B Truncation Policy With Hard Bandwidth Constraint

Note that the hard constraint C3 is not guaranteed to be satisfied under the optimal relaxed policy π¯∗superscript¯𝜋\overline{\pi}^{*}. To address this issue, we construct a new truncation policy π~~𝜋\tilde{\pi} based on π¯∗superscript¯𝜋\overline{\pi}^{*} to meet the hard constraint C3. Denote Ω¯tsubscript¯Ω𝑡\overline{\Omega}_{t} as the set of scheduled devices at time slot t𝑡t under the optimal relaxed policy π¯∗superscript¯𝜋\overline{\pi}^{*}. The truncation policy π~~𝜋\tilde{\pi} at each time slot is carried out in two cases as follows:

  • •

    If |Ω¯t|≤Rsubscript¯Ω𝑡𝑅|\overline{\Omega}_{t}|\leq R, all devices n∈Ω¯t𝑛subscript¯Ω𝑡n\in\overline{\Omega}_{t} can upload their local gradients.

  • •

    Otherwise if |Ω¯t|>Rsubscript¯Ω𝑡𝑅|\overline{\Omega}_{t}|>R, the server schedules a subset of devices Ω~t⊆Ω¯tsubscript~Ω𝑡subscript¯Ω𝑡\tilde{\Omega}_{t}\subseteq\overline{\Omega}_{t} randomly such that |Ω~t|=Rsubscript~Ω𝑡𝑅|\tilde{\Omega}_{t}|=R. Those devices that are in set Ω¯tsubscript¯Ω𝑡\overline{\Omega}_{t} but not selected in Ω~tsubscript~Ω𝑡\tilde{\Omega}_{t} will not be scheduled to transmit.

V-C Asymptotic Optimality of the Relax-and-Truncate Policy

In this subsection, we analyze the asymptotic optimality of the proposed relax-and-truncate policy. We establish an upper bound for the gap between the expected cumulative costs under the truncation policy π~~𝜋\tilde{\pi} and the optimal policy π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} in the following theorem.

Theorem 5.

Assume that the proportion of scheduled devices, κ=RN𝜅𝑅𝑁\kappa=\frac{R}{N}, remains constant. The gap between the expected cumulative costs under the truncation policy π~~𝜋\tilde{\pi} and the optimal policy π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} is upper bounded by

J​(π~)−J​(π∗)≤η​ρ​T2​κ​Dmin​N=𝒪​(1N),𝐽~𝜋𝐽superscript𝜋𝜂𝜌𝑇2𝜅subscript𝐷min𝑁𝒪1𝑁\displaystyle J(\tilde{\pi})-J(\pi^{*})\leq\frac{\eta\rho T}{2\kappa D_{\textup{min}}\sqrt{N}}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right), (44)

where Dmin=minn⁡{Dn}subscript𝐷minsubscript𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛D_{\textup{min}}=\min_{n}\left\{D_{n}\right\}.

Proof.

The proof is presented in Appendix E. ∎

Remark 3.

According to Theorem 5, when κ=RN𝜅𝑅𝑁\kappa=\frac{R}{N} is fixed, the cost gap between the proposed relax-and-truncate policy π~~𝜋\tilde{\pi} and the optimal policy π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} is 𝒪​(1N)𝒪1𝑁\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right). As N𝑁N increases, the gap approaches zero. Thus, the proposed relax-and-truncate policy is asymptotically optimal for Problem 1 with hard bandwidth constraint.

VI Structure-Enhanced Deep Reinforcement Learning

In this section, we address a more general scenario in which the statistical knowledge of channels and harvested energy is unknown. To this end, we develop a novel structure-enhanced Deep Q-Network (SE-DQN) algorithm that leverages the monotone structure of the optimal policy to improve offline training performance.

VI-A Deep Reinforcement Learning

Solving the MDP formulated in Section IV requires the statistical knowledge of channels and harvested energy. However, this information may be unknown a priori in practice (e.g., edge devices are deployed in unknown or time-varying environments). To address this challenge, the DQN algorithm has been widely adopted [33]. DQN is an extension of the Q-learning algorithm, which uses a state-action value function, known as the Q-function, to estimate the quality of state-action pairs. In the context of the MDP defined in Problem 1, the update rule for the Q-function in Q-learning is given by

Q​(𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t)𝑄subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡\displaystyle Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}) (45)
=\displaystyle= c​(𝒉t,𝒑t)+A−1​𝔼​[min𝒑t+1∈𝒫t+1⁡{Q​(𝒉t+1,𝒃t+1,𝒑t+1)}|𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t].𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐴1𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsubscript𝒑𝑡1subscript𝒫𝑡1𝑄subscript𝒉𝑡1subscript𝒃𝑡1subscript𝒑𝑡1subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡\displaystyle c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})\!+\!A^{\!-1}\mathbb{E}\!\!\left[\min_{\!\boldsymbol{p}_{t+1}\!\in\mathcal{P}_{t+1}}\!\!\!\left\{\!Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{b}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{p}_{t+1})\!\right\}\!\!|\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\right]\!\!.

To effectively handle large state and action spaces, DQN approximates the Q-function using a neural network with parameters 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}, denoted as Q​(𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t;𝜽)𝑄subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝜽Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}). To train the DQN, a dataset of experiences is first collected by interacting with the environment, with each experience containing the current state, the action taken, the resulting cost, and the next state. Then, the parameters 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} of DQN are optimized by minimizing the temporal difference (TD) error, which is defined as

TD≜yt−Q​(𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t;𝜽),≜TDsubscript𝑦𝑡𝑄subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝜽\displaystyle\textup{TD}\triangleq y_{t}-Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}), (46)

where ytsubscript𝑦𝑡y_{t} is the target value defined as

yt=c​(𝒉t,𝒑t)+A−1​min𝒑t+1∈𝒫t+1⁡Q​(𝒉t+1,𝒃t+1,𝒑t+1;𝜽′),subscript𝑦𝑡𝑐subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐴1subscriptsubscript𝒑𝑡1subscript𝒫𝑡1𝑄subscript𝒉𝑡1subscript𝒃𝑡1subscript𝒑𝑡1superscript𝜽′\displaystyle y_{t}=c(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t})+A^{-1}\min_{\!\!\boldsymbol{p}_{t+1\!}\in\mathcal{P}_{t+1}\!\!}Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{b}_{t+1},\boldsymbol{p}_{t+1};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}), (47)

with 𝜽′superscript𝜽′\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime} being the parameters of a target network that stabilizes the training process. By minimizing the TD error, the DQN aligns its estimations with both immediate and future costs, guiding it towards the optimal policy.

VI-B Algorithm Development

The standard DQN algorithm dose not utilize the structural properties of the policy. In this subsection, we develop an SE-DQN algorithm that leverages the monotone structure obtained in Theorems 3 and 4 to improve offline training performance. Specifically, we propose 1) an SE action selection method based on the monotone structure to select reasonable actions; and 2) an SE loss function to penalize actions that do not follow the monotone structure. We present the SE action selection method and the SE loss function in the following.

VI-B1 SE Action Selection

The monotone structure implies that the optimal actions of a state and its adjacent states are related. Thus, we can infer the optimal action for a given state according to the actions taken by adjacent states. At each time slot t𝑡t, given the observed state (𝒉t,𝒃t)subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}), we first compute the actions of its adjacent states as follows:

𝒑t+=arg​min𝒑t∈𝒫t⁡Q​(𝒉t−,𝒃t+,𝒑t;𝜽),subscriptsuperscript𝒑𝑡subscriptargminsubscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝒫𝑡𝑄subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝜽\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{p}}^{+}_{t}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}Q(\boldsymbol{h}^{-}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}^{+},\boldsymbol{p}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}), (48)
𝒑t−=arg​min𝒑t∈𝒫t⁡Q​(𝒉t+,𝒃t−,𝒑t;𝜽),subscriptsuperscript𝒑𝑡subscriptargminsubscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝒫𝑡𝑄subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝜽\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{p}}^{-}_{t}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}Q(\boldsymbol{h}^{+}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t}^{-},\boldsymbol{p}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}),

where 𝒉t−=𝒉t−𝟏subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒉𝑡1\boldsymbol{h}^{-}_{t}=\boldsymbol{h}_{t}-\boldsymbol{1}, 𝒉t+=𝒉t+𝟏subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒉𝑡1\boldsymbol{h}^{+}_{t}=\boldsymbol{h}_{t}+\boldsymbol{1}, 𝒃t−=𝒃t−𝟏subscriptsuperscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡1\boldsymbol{b}^{-}_{t}=\boldsymbol{b}_{t}-\boldsymbol{1}, 𝒃t+=𝒃t+𝟏subscriptsuperscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡1\boldsymbol{b}^{+}_{t}=\boldsymbol{b}_{t}+\boldsymbol{1}, and 𝟏1\boldsymbol{1} denotes the all-ones vector. Then, we check whether there exist any actions 𝒑^t∈𝒫tsubscript^𝒑𝑡subscript𝒫𝑡\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}_{t} satisfying

𝒑t−≤𝒑^t≤𝒑t+.subscriptsuperscript𝒑𝑡subscript^𝒑𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒑𝑡\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{p}}^{-}_{t}\leq\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}\leq{\boldsymbol{p}}^{+}_{t}. (49)

If such actions 𝒑^tsubscript^𝒑𝑡\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}, referred to as the SE actions, exist, one of them is randomly selected for execution. Otherwise, if no SE action exists, we execute the greedy action 𝒑~tsubscript~𝒑𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}, which is generated according to the standard DQN algorithm as follows:

𝒑~t=arg​min𝒑t∈𝒫t⁡Q​(𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑t;𝜽).subscript~𝒑𝑡subscriptargminsubscript𝒑𝑡subscript𝒫𝑡𝑄subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript𝒑𝑡𝜽\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\boldsymbol{p}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}). (50)

VI-B2 SE Loss Function

Different from the standard DQN, we develop an action difference (AD) error, which measures the difference between the Q-values of the SE action 𝒑^tsubscript^𝒑𝑡\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t} and the greedy action 𝒑~tsubscript~𝒑𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t} as follows:

AD≜Q​(𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑^t;𝜽)−Q​(𝒉t,𝒃t,𝒑~t;𝜽).≜AD𝑄subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript^𝒑𝑡𝜽𝑄subscript𝒉𝑡subscript𝒃𝑡subscript~𝒑𝑡𝜽\displaystyle\textup{AD}\triangleq Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta})-Q(\boldsymbol{h}_{t},\boldsymbol{b}_{t},\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t};\boldsymbol{\theta}). (51)

Since the optimal policy has a monotone structure, the SE action 𝒑^tsubscript^𝒑𝑡\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t} should be close to the greedy action 𝒑~tsubscript~𝒑𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}_{t}. Thus, DQN should minimize the AD error. By combining the TD error and AD error, we define the SE loss function as

L​(𝜽)=α​TD2+(1−α)​AD2,𝐿𝜽𝛼superscriptTD21𝛼superscriptAD2\displaystyle L(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\alpha\textup{TD}^{2}+(1-\alpha)\textup{AD}^{2}, (52)

where α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1) is a hyperparameter to balance the importance of the TD error and AD error. To optimize 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}, we minimize the SE loss function L​(𝜽)𝐿𝜽L(\boldsymbol{\theta}) by adopting stochastic gradient descent (SGD). The proposed SE-DQN algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 2. In Section VII-C, the performance of the proposed SE-DQN algorithm is evaluated and compared with the standard DQN algorithm.

VII Simulation Results

In this section, we validate the theoretical results and evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithms through numerical experiments on real datasets.

VII-A Simulation Setups

VII-A1 Learning Model Setting

The proposed algorithms are evaluated by implementing the image classification tasks on the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. For the MNIST dataset, we employ the regularized multinomial logistic regression model, with the loss function defined as follows:

f​(𝒘;𝒙n,i,yn,i)𝑓𝒘subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖\displaystyle f(\boldsymbol{w};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}) (53)
=\displaystyle= −∑c=1C𝟙{yn,i=c}​log⁡(exp⁡(𝒘c𝖳​𝒙n,i)∑j=1Cexp⁡(𝒘j𝖳​𝒙n,i))+αr2​∑c=1C‖𝒘c‖2,superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶subscript1subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖𝑐superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑐𝖳subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐶superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑗𝖳subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝛼𝑟2superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶superscriptnormsubscript𝒘𝑐2\displaystyle\!-\!\sum_{c=1}^{C}\mathbbm{1}_{\!\left\{y_{n,i}=c\right\}}\!\log\!\left(\!\frac{\exp\!\left(\boldsymbol{w}_{c}^{\mathsf{T}}\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i}\right)}{\sum_{j=1}^{C}\exp\!\left(\boldsymbol{w}_{j}^{\mathsf{T}}\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i}\right)}\!\right)\!+\!\frac{\alpha_{r}}{2}\sum_{c=1}^{C}\|\boldsymbol{w}_{c}\|^{2},

where C𝐶C represents the total number of label categories in the dataset, 𝒘csubscript𝒘𝑐\boldsymbol{w}_{c} denotes the model parameter vector associated with label category c∈[C]𝑐delimited-[]𝐶c\in[C], and αr=0.01subscript𝛼𝑟0.01\alpha_{r}=0.01. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, we train a convolutional neural network (CNN) with the following structure: four 3×3333\times 3 convolution layers each with 64 channels and followed by a 2×2222\times 2 max pooling layer, a fully connected layer with 120 units, and finally a 10-unit softmax output layer. Each convolution or fully connected layer is activated by a ReLU function. Both the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets are randomly and uniformly partitioned into N𝑁N disjoint subsets, and each device holds one subset as its local training dataset. We set the learning rate η𝜂\eta as 0.01 for the MNIST dataset and 0.05 for the CIFAR-10 dataset.

VII-A2 Communication Model Setting

The wireless channels from edge devices to the server follow Rayleigh fading and can be modeled as finite-state Markov channels [34]. It is assumed that the current channel state either remains constant or transitions to adjacent states in the next time slot, which is suitable for slow fading channels. The channel transition probability from state Hisubscript𝐻𝑖H_{i} to state Hjsubscript𝐻𝑗H_{j} can be approximated as follows [28]:

ℙ​(hn,t+1=Hj|hn,t=Hi)ℙsubscriptℎ𝑛𝑡1conditionalsubscript𝐻𝑗subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝐻𝑖\displaystyle\mathbb{P}(h_{n,t+1}=H_{j}|h_{n,t}=H_{i}) (54)
={Z​(Hi+1)​τℙ​(Hi), if ​j=i+1,Z​(Hi)​τℙ​(Hi), if ​j=i−1,1−Z​(Hi+1)​τℙ​(Hi)−Z​(Hi)​τℙ​(Hi), if ​j=i,absentcases𝑍subscript𝐻𝑖1𝜏ℙsubscript𝐻𝑖 if 𝑗𝑖1𝑍subscript𝐻𝑖𝜏ℙsubscript𝐻𝑖 if 𝑗𝑖11𝑍subscript𝐻𝑖1𝜏ℙsubscript𝐻𝑖𝑍subscript𝐻𝑖𝜏ℙsubscript𝐻𝑖 if 𝑗𝑖\displaystyle=\begin{cases}\frac{Z(H_{i+1})\tau}{\mathbb{P}({H_{i}})},&\text{ if }j=i+1,\\ \frac{Z(H_{i})\tau}{\mathbb{P}({H_{i}})},&\text{ if }j=i-1,\\ 1-\frac{Z(H_{i+1})\tau}{\mathbb{P}({H_{i}})}-\frac{Z(H_{i})\tau}{\mathbb{P}({H_{i}})},&\text{ if }j=i,\end{cases}

where Z​(Hi)𝑍subscript𝐻𝑖Z(H_{i}) is the level crossing rate of channel state Hisubscript𝐻𝑖H_{i}, ℙ​(Hi)ℙsubscript𝐻𝑖\mathbb{P}({H_{i}}) is the steady probability of channel state Hisubscript𝐻𝑖H_{i}, and τ𝜏\tau is the duration of one time slot.

For the energy harvesting model, we employ a realistic data record of the irradiance (i.e., the intensity of the solar radiation in units μ𝜇\muW/cm2superscriptcm2\text{cm}^{2}) for the month of June from 2008 to 2010, measured at a solar site in Elizabeth City State University [35]. Since edge devices are small, the solar panel area is set as 1 cm2superscriptcm2\text{cm}^{2}. The energy conversion efficiency is assumed to be 20%percent2020\% and we assume that the battery state is randomly initialized.

VII-B Asymptotically Optimal Performance of the Relax-and-Truncate Policy

In this subsection, we empirically validate the asymptotic optimality of the relax-and-truncate policy, as established in Theorem 5. We conduct a classification task on the MNIST dataset to compare the learning performance of the relax-and-truncate policy with the optimal policy. Fig. 3 demonstrates the test accuracy for the number of devices N𝑁N ranging from 20 to 200 with a bandwidth of R=0.4​N𝑅0.4𝑁R=0.4N. As observed, the performance gap between these two policies diminishes as N𝑁N increases, which corroborates our theoretical result.

VII-C Offline Training Performance of the SE-DQN Algorithm

In this subsection, we compare the offline training performance of the proposed SE-DQN algorithm with the standard DQN algorithm. Moreover, to demonstrate the necessity of both SE action selection and SE loss function in the SE-DQN algorithm, we also compare the complete SE-DQN with a variant that disables the SE loss function (i.e., setting α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 in (52)). The neural networks of DQN and SE-DQN have identical hyperparameters, each consisting of two fully connected layers with 256 units. Fig. 4 illustrates the optimality gap (i.e., the objective value of Problem 1) achieved by DQN, SE-DQN, and SE-DQN without the SE loss function. As observed, SE-DQN reduces the optimality gap by 25%percent2525\% compared to the DQN algorithm. Furthermore, disabling the SE loss function doubles the training convergence time of the SE-DQN algorithm. Thus, both SE action selection and SE loss function in the SE-DQN algorithm are essential for guaranteeing its offline training performance.

VII-D Comparison With Benchmark Schemes

In this subsection, we demonstrate the superiority of the proposed algorithms to the following three benchmark schemes.

  • •

    Optimal Benchmark: All devices have sufficient energy and bandwidth to upload local gradients without packet drops. This benchmark achieves the ideal performance by completely ignoring the negative effects of wireless channels. However, it is infeasible in practical wireless systems.

  • •

    Greedy Optimality Gap Minimization: At each time slot t𝑡t, the server schedules all devices that have remaining battery energy. If the number of eligible devices exceeds R𝑅R, the server selects the R𝑅R devices with best channel conditions. Each scheduled device depletes its remaining energy to upload the local gradient.

  • •

    Lyapunov-Based Online Optimization: This benchmark employs Lyapunov optimization framework for online optimization [19]. At each time slot t𝑡t, it adopts Gibbs sampling for device scheduling. Then, each scheduled device determines its transmission power by solving the per-time-slot subproblem as follows:

    minpn,tsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑡min\displaystyle\underset{p_{n,t}}{\text{min}}{}{} V​η​ρ​AT−t​qn,t​(hn,t,pn,t)2​N​Dn+Qn,t​en,t𝑉𝜂𝜌superscript𝐴𝑇𝑡subscript𝑞𝑛𝑡subscriptℎ𝑛𝑡subscript𝑝𝑛𝑡2𝑁subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑄𝑛𝑡subscript𝑒𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\frac{V\eta\rho A^{T-t}q_{n,t}(h_{n,t},p_{n,t})}{2ND_{n}}+Q_{n,t}e_{n,t} (55)
    s.t.  0≤en,t≤bn,t, 0subscript𝑒𝑛𝑡subscript𝑏𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\;0\leq e_{n,t}\leq b_{n,t},

    where V>0𝑉0V>0 is a tradeoff hyperparameter, and Qn,tsubscript𝑄𝑛𝑡Q_{n,t} is the virtual queue of device n𝑛n. The queuing dynamics of Qn,tsubscript𝑄𝑛𝑡Q_{n,t} is given by

    Qn,t+1=Qn,t+en,t−un,t.subscript𝑄𝑛𝑡1subscript𝑄𝑛𝑡subscript𝑒𝑛𝑡subscript𝑢𝑛𝑡\displaystyle Q_{n,t+1}=Q_{n,t}+e_{n,t}-u_{n,t}. (56)

In Fig. 5, we compare the learning performance of the proposed algorithms with benchmark schemes on the MNIST dataset. We consider N=200𝑁200N=200 edge devices with a total bandwidth of R=100𝑅100R=100. As observed, the proposed algorithms achieve near-optimal learning performance and outperform other benchmarks. The greedy optimality gap minimization scheme myopically uses up all remaining energy at each time slot, leading to poor performance in subsequent time slots. The Lyapunov-based online optimization scheme does not utilize the statistical knowledge of system dynamics, e.g., the distributions of the channel gains and the amount of harvested energy, resulting in poor long-term performance. In contrast, the proposed algorithms leverage the previously known or learned knowledge of channel and energy dynamics to design the transmission policy from a long-term perspective, thereby improving the learning performance.

Fig. 6 shows a similar comparison on the CIFAR-10 dataset. To demonstrate the wide applicability of the proposed algorithms, we implement CNNs as the classifier model, which does not satisfy Assumptions 1 and 2. Despite this, similar empirical performance trends can be observed and our proposed algorithms still outperform other benchmarks, except for the optimal benchmark scheme.

In Fig. 7, we compare the proposed algorithms with other benchmarks under different battery capacities on the MNIST dataset. As can be observed, our proposed algorithms exhibit considerable performance improvements under different battery capacities. For all schemes, the test accuracy increases with battery capacity, since smaller capacities lead to quicker saturation and potential waste of harvested energy. However, once the battery capacity exceeds 9, the accuracy of other benchmarks plateaus, whereas the proposed algorithms continue to exhibit improvement. This divergence can be attributed to the benchmarks’ neglect of battery capacity limitations in their algorithm design. In contrast, the proposed algorithms leverage increased battery capacity to improve state representation and decision-making flexibility, thereby enhancing the learning performance.

VIII Conclusion

In this paper, we have studied FL with EH devices. We have conducted convergence analysis to demonstrate the influence of transmission policy on the learning performance. Based on the convergence bound, we have formulated a joint device scheduling and power control problem to minimize the optimality gap under energy and bandwidth constraints. We have further modeled this optimization problem as an MDP and demonstrated that its optimal policy possesses a monotone structure. We have also proposed a low-complexity relax-and-truncate algorithm that is asymptotically optimal as the number of devices increases. Moreover, for unknown channels and harvested energy statistics, we have developed an SE-DQN algorithm that leverages the monotone structure of the optimal policy to improve the training performance. Finally, extensive numerical experiments have been presented to validate the theoretical results and the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms.
